001package io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost;
002
003import org.immutables.value.Value;
004
005import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonDeserialize;
006import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonSerialize;
007
008import io.github.ai4ci.config.execution.DemographicAdjustment;
009import io.github.ai4ci.functions.Distribution;
010import io.github.ai4ci.functions.SimpleDistribution;
011
012/**
013 * Configuration for an in‑host phenomenological model.
014 *
015 * <p>
016 * This interface captures the distributions and thresholds used by the
017 * phenomenological in‑host model. It includes parameters for incubation, timing
018 * of peak viral load and recovery, approximate peak viral load and immune
019 * response, and immune waning.
020 *
021 * <p>
022 * Several entries are subject to demographic adjustment via
023 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.config.execution.DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological}
024 * and may be modified at runtime by the execution configuration. In particular
025 * the following getters are adjustable by demographic factors:
026 * <ul>
027 * <li>{@link #getIncubationPeriod()}</li>
028 * <li>{@link #getPeakToRecoveryDelay()}</li>
029 * <li>{@link #getImmuneWaningHalfLife()}</li>
030 * </ul>
031 *
032 * <p>
033 * Downstream uses include the initialiser
034 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultInHostPhenomenologicalStateInitialiser}
035 * which samples these distributions to build an
036 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost.InHostPhenomenologicalState}. It is also
037 * referenced by example code and tests.
038 *
039 * @author Rob Challen
040 */
041@Value.Immutable
042//@JsonTypeInfo(use = Id.NAME, requireTypeIdForSubtypes = OptBoolean.FALSE, defaultImpl = ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel.class)
043//@JsonSubTypes({
044//  @Type(value=ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel.class, name="complete"),
045//  @Type(value=PartialPhenomenologicalModel.class, name="partial")
046//})
047@JsonSerialize(as = ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel.class)
048@JsonDeserialize(as = ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel.class)
049public interface PhenomenologicalModel extends InHostConfiguration,
050                DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological<Distribution, Double> {
051
052        /**
053         * A sensible default parameterisation of the phenomenological model.
054         *
055         * <p>
056         * The default values provide a compact set of distributions used in examples
057         * and tests. Downstream callers that rely on this simple default include the
058         * default in‑host phenomenological initialiser and example experiments.
059         *
060         * @see io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultInHostPhenomenologicalStateInitialiser
061         */
062        public static ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel DEFAULT = ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel
063                        .builder()
064
065                        // .setSymptomCutoff(0.5)
066                        .setInfectiousnessCutoff(0.2)
067
068                        .setIncubationPeriod(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(4D, 2D))
069                        .setApproxPeakViralLoad(SimpleDistribution.unimodalBeta(0.5, 0.1))
070                        .setIncubationToPeakViralLoadDelay(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(2D, 1D))
071                        .setPeakToRecoveryDelay(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(6D, 3D))
072
073                        .setApproxPeakImmuneResponse(SimpleDistribution.unimodalBeta(0.5, 0.1))
074                        .setImmuneWaningHalfLife(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(300D, 10D))
075                        .setPeakImmuneResponseDelay(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(20D, 4D))
076
077                        .build();
078
079        /**
080         * Approximate distribution for peak immune response.
081         *
082         * <p>
083         * This is used in the phenomenological immune model to determine the
084         * amplitude of the host immune response and its effect on viral decay. It is
085         * not adjusted via the demographic adjustment interface in the standard
086         * configuration.
087         *
088         * @return the peak immune response
089         */
090        Distribution getApproxPeakImmuneResponse();
091
092        /**
093         * Approximate distribution for peak viral load or its proxy.
094         *
095         * <p>
096         * This value is used to calibrate the shape and amplitude of the viral load
097         * trajectory. It is not directly adjusted by the demographic adjustment
098         * component in the current design.
099         *
100         * @return the peak viral load
101         */
102        Distribution getApproxPeakViralLoad();
103
104        /**
105         * Distribution for the half life of waning immunity.
106         *
107         * <p>
108         * This parameter may be adjusted by
109         * {@link DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological} implementations to
110         * represent age dependent differences in immune waning. Callers such as
111         * initialisers and immune decay updaters sample this distribution when
112         * computing immunity loss over time.
113         *
114         * @return the immune waning half life
115         */
116        @Override
117        Distribution getImmuneWaningHalfLife();
118
119        /**
120         * Distribution for the incubation period (time from infection to onset).
121         *
122         * <p>
123         * This distribution is sampled by the default initialiser and by the viral
124         * load calibration code. It is adjustable by
125         * {@link DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological} implementations, allowing
126         * age dependent scaling of incubation timing.
127         *
128         * @return the incubation periods
129         */
130        @Override
131        Distribution getIncubationPeriod();
132
133        /**
134         * Delay from incubation/onset to peak viral load.
135         *
136         * <p>
137         * This distribution is sampled when constructing the viral load model for an
138         * infected individual. It is not listed as adjustable in the
139         * {@link DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological} interface and so remains
140         * constant across demographic groups unless modified elsewhere.
141         *
142         * @return the delay from onset to peak viral load
143         */
144        Distribution getIncubationToPeakViralLoadDelay();
145
146        /**
147         * Cutoff of the viral load or proxy used to determine infectiousness.
148         *
149         * <p>
150         * Value is used by initialisers and state code to determine whether an
151         * individual is infectious at a given point on their viral load curve.
152         *
153         * @return infectiousness cutoff in the unit interval
154         */
155        Double getInfectiousnessCutoff();
156
157        /**
158         * Delay from infection/onset to peak immune response.
159         *
160         * <p>
161         * This distribution is sampled when creating an individual's immune response
162         * trajectory and is used by the viral load/immune interaction routines.
163         *
164         * @return the delay to peak immune response
165         */
166        Distribution getPeakImmuneResponseDelay();
167
168        /**
169         * Delay from peak viral load to recovery.
170         *
171         * <p>
172         * The {@link DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological} may adjust this value
173         * via the {@code getPeakToRecoveryDelay} entry in certain demographic
174         * configurations; callers should consult the execution configuration's
175         * demographic adjustment before sampling if age dependent values are
176         * required.
177         *
178         * @return the delay from peak to recovery
179         */
180        @Override
181        Distribution getPeakToRecoveryDelay();
182
183}
